blockDescription: Installs drywall, ceilings, flooring, interior doors, trim and finish components, including stairs.

questions.question: What is the standard thickness of drywall used for walls in residential construction?

explanations.A: This thickness is too thin and used only for curved surfaces or repairs
explanations.B: This thickness is sometimes used but not the standard for walls
explanations.C: 13 mm (1/2 in.) drywall is the standard thickness for residential walls, providing adequate strength and fire resistance
explanations.D: This thickness is typically used for ceilings or fire-rated assemblies, not standard walls

questions.question: What is the maximum spacing for drywall screws on walls when fastening to wood studs?

explanations.A: This spacing is tighter than necessary for walls
explanations.B: While acceptable, this exceeds the minimum requirement
explanations.C: This is the maximum for ceiling applications, not walls
explanations.D: For walls, drywall screws should be spaced maximum 400 mm (16 in.) o.c. on wood studs, with screws placed on all edges and in the field

questions.question: How many coats of joint compound are typically required for a smooth finish?

explanations.A: One coat is insufficient for a smooth, professional finish
explanations.B: Two coats leave visible imperfections and tape edges
explanations.C: Three coats are standard: first coat (taping), second coat (fill/block), and third coat (finish/skim) to achieve a smooth, level surface
explanations.D: Four coats are excessive for standard applications

questions.question: What type of drywall should be used in high-moisture areas like bathrooms?

options.C: Moisture-resistant drywall (green board or purple board)

explanations.A: Standard drywall deteriorates rapidly in high-moisture environments
explanations.B: Fire-rated drywall provides fire protection but not moisture resistance
explanations.C: Moisture-resistant drywall (green board, purple board, or paperless) has treated core and facings that resist mold growth and moisture damage
explanations.D: Foil backing provides vapor barrier but not moisture resistance for the core

questions.question: What is the purpose of sanding between coats of joint compound?

options.A: To roughen the surface for better adhesion
options.B: To remove ridges, bumps, and excess compound
options.C: To open the pores of the paper
options.D: Sanding between coats is not necessary

explanations.A: Good adhesion occurs without sanding when compound is still slightly damp
explanations.B: Sanding removes high spots, tool marks, and excess compound, creating a smooth surface for the next coat
explanations.C: The paper doesn't need pore opening for compound adhesion
explanations.D: Sanding between coats is essential for a quality finish

questions.question: How far should drywall screws be placed from the edge of the board?

explanations.A: This distance is too close and risks edge crumbling
explanations.B: Screws should be placed approximately 10 mm (3/8 in.) from edges to prevent crumbling while ensuring secure attachment
explanations.C: This distance is acceptable but further than necessary
explanations.D: This distance is excessive and doesn't provide adequate edge support

questions.subtask: F-17.03 Installs panels, tiles, solid wood finishes
questions.question: What is the standard panel size for 4x8 sheet products in interior wall paneling?

options.A: 1200 mm x 2400 mm (4 ft. x 8 ft.)
options.B: 1220 mm x 2440 mm (4 ft. x 8 ft.)
options.C: 1200 mm x 3000 mm (4 ft. x 10 ft.)
options.D: 1500 mm x 2400 mm (5 ft. x 8 ft.)

explanations.A: This is close but not the actual standard dimension
explanations.B: Standard sheet goods are 1220 mm x 2440 mm (4 ft. x 8 ft.), which matches standard wall heights and stud spacing
explanations.C: This represents 4x10 sheets, not standard 4x8
explanations.D: This is not a standard panel size

questions.question: What is the proper way to install drywall on walls?

options.C: Horizontally is preferred to reduce seams

explanations.A: Vertical installation creates more seams and is less efficient
explanations.B: While horizontal is preferred, vertical is sometimes necessary
explanations.C: Horizontal installation is preferred because it reduces the number of seams, creates stronger joints at mid-wall height, and is more efficient
explanations.D: Installation direction significantly affects finish quality and efficiency

questions.question: What type of joint compound is best for the first coat (taping coat)?

explanations.A: Lightweight compound can be used but isn't specifically designed for tape embedment
explanations.B: Taping compound or all-purpose compound has stronger bonding properties and is specifically formulated for tape embedment
explanations.C: Topping compound is too soft for tape embedment and provides insufficient bonding
explanations.D: While setting-type can be used by professionals, it's not necessary for standard first coat

questions.question: What is the standard grid size for suspended ceiling tile systems?

options.A: 300 mm x 300 mm (1 ft. x 1 ft.)
options.C: 600 mm x 600 mm (2 ft. x 2 ft.)
options.D: 900 mm x 900 mm (3 ft. x 3 ft.)

explanations.A: This size is too small and not standard
explanations.B: This is not a standard ceiling tile size
explanations.C: 600 mm x 600 mm (2 ft. x 2 ft.) is the most common standard size for suspended ceiling tiles, though 600 mm x 1200 mm is also used
explanations.D: This size is too large for standard ceiling systems

questions.question: What should be done to outside corners before drywall installation?

explanations.A: Outside corners require protection and finishing
explanations.B: Corner bead is installed after drywall is hung, protecting the vulnerable corner and providing a straight edge for compound application
explanations.C: Corner bead is applied over the drywall corner, not to bare framing
explanations.D: Stud doubling is for structural purposes, not corner finishing

questions.question: How wide should the final coat of joint compound be feathered?

explanations.A: This width is too narrow and will show a ridge
explanations.B: Still too narrow for proper feathering
explanations.C: The final coat should be feathered 250-300 mm (10-12 in.) wide to create an imperceptible transition to the drywall surface
explanations.D: While providing good transition, this is wider than necessary

questions.subtask: F-17.03 Installs panels, tiles, solid wood finishes
questions.question: What type of adhesive is commonly used for installing decorative wall paneling?

explanations.A: White glue lacks the strength for panel installation
explanations.B: Panel adhesive or construction adhesive provides strong, flexible bonds specifically formulated for wall panel installation
explanations.C: Carpenter's glue is for wood joints, not panel installation
explanations.D: Contact cement is used for laminates, not wall panels

questions.question: What is the minimum clearance typically required for a suspended ceiling installation?

explanations.A: This clearance is insufficient for grid installation
explanations.B: Still too tight for proper grid and tile installation
explanations.C: Minimal but often insufficient for mechanical systems
explanations.D: A minimum 100 mm (4 in.) clearance is typically required to accommodate the grid system, though more is needed if mechanical systems must be concealed

questions.question: What is the purpose of leaving a small gap at the bottom of drywall sheets?

options.C: To prevent moisture wicking from floor and allow for baseboard installation

explanations.A: Material savings is not the purpose of the gap
explanations.B: Floor adjustment is not related to drywall gaps
explanations.C: A 10-15 mm gap prevents moisture from wicking into the drywall from the floor and allows space for baseboard installation over irregularities
explanations.D: The gap is not for ventilation purposes

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of demountable partition systems?

options.C: Can be relocated and reconfigured without waste

explanations.A: Demountable systems typically cost more initially than drywall
explanations.B: Sound insulation depends on design; not inherently better
explanations.C: Demountable systems can be disassembled, moved, and reconfigured with minimal waste, making them ideal for flexible office spaces
explanations.D: Paint application is similar to or more difficult than standard walls

questions.question: What grit sandpaper is typically used for final sanding of joint compound?

explanations.A: Coarse grit would scratch and damage the surface
explanations.B: Medium-coarse grit can leave visible scratches
explanations.C: 120 grit sandpaper provides a smooth finish without over-sanding or creating visible scratches in the compound
explanations.D: Very fine grit is unnecessary and less efficient for compound

questions.question: How should drywall screws be driven into the board?

options.B: Slightly countersunk below the surface without breaking paper

explanations.A: Flush screws are difficult to cover with compound
explanations.B: Screws should be slightly countersunk (dimpled) to allow compound coverage while keeping the paper intact for maximum holding power
explanations.C: Protruding screws will show through finish and aren't properly secured
explanations.D: Over-driving breaks the paper and reduces holding strength

questions.subtask: F-17.03 Installs panels, tiles, solid wood finishes
questions.question: When installing tongue and groove wood paneling, which direction should installation proceed?

options.C: From one side to the other, with groove facing the starting wall

explanations.A: Direction depends on room layout and groove orientation
explanations.B: Either direction works if properly oriented
explanations.C: Installation should proceed from one side with the groove edge toward the starting wall, allowing the tongue to insert into each successive board
explanations.D: Center-out installation is impractical for tongue and groove

questions.question: What is the maximum spacing for hanger wires supporting suspended ceiling main runners?

explanations.A: This spacing is tighter than necessary
explanations.B: While conservative, this isn't the standard maximum
explanations.C: Hanger wires should be spaced maximum 1200 mm (4 ft.) o.c. along main runners to prevent sagging
explanations.D: This spacing is too wide and would allow sagging

questions.question: What is the purpose of mesh tape versus paper tape for drywall joints?

options.A: Mesh is stronger in all applications
options.B: Mesh is self-adhesive and faster to apply but may need setting compound

explanations.A: Paper tape is actually stronger when properly embedded
explanations.B: Mesh tape is self-adhesive for quick application but requires setting-type or all-purpose compound for adequate strength; paper tape is stronger when embedded
explanations.C: Mesh can be used on flat seams, not just corners
explanations.D: The tapes have significant differences in application and performance

questions.question: What is the recommended maximum spacing for drywall screws on ceilings?

explanations.A: This spacing is tighter than necessary
explanations.B: While acceptable, this exceeds minimum requirements
explanations.C: Ceiling drywall requires screws at maximum 300 mm (12 in.) o.c. due to gravity loads, which is tighter than wall spacing
explanations.D: This spacing is too wide for ceilings and will cause sagging

questions.question: How should wall angles be installed for a suspended ceiling system?

explanations.A: Wall angles must be installed level around the entire room to ensure the ceiling grid and tiles are level, regardless of floor irregularities
explanations.B: Following floor would create an unlevel ceiling
explanations.C: Interior ceilings should be level, not sloped
explanations.D: Wall angles attach to walls, not ceiling joists

questions.subtask: F-17.03 Installs panels, tiles, solid wood finishes
questions.question: What expansion gap should be left when installing solid wood wall paneling?

explanations.A: Wood expands and contracts with humidity changes
explanations.B: This gap is too small for seasonal wood movement
explanations.C: A 3-6 mm expansion gap allows for seasonal wood movement without buckling, covered by trim
explanations.D: This gap is excessive and difficult to conceal with trim

questions.question: What is the standard thickness of plywood underlayment for resilient flooring?

explanations.A: This thickness is too thin for adequate support
explanations.B: 6 mm (1/4 in.) plywood underlayment is standard for resilient flooring, providing a smooth, stable surface
explanations.C: This thickness is acceptable but thicker than necessary
explanations.D: This thickness is excessive for underlayment purposes

questions.question: What is the recommended acclimation time for hardwood flooring before installation?

explanations.A: Acclimation is essential to prevent expansion/contraction issues
explanations.B: 24 hours is insufficient for wood to adjust to site conditions
explanations.C: Hardwood flooring should acclimate 3-5 days minimum (sometimes longer) to adjust to the installation environment's temperature and humidity
explanations.D: While longer acclimation doesn't hurt, 30 days is excessive

questions.question: How should underlayment panels be fastened?

options.C: Ring shank nails or screws at 150 mm o.c. along edges, 200 mm in field

explanations.A: Adhesive alone doesn't provide adequate holding
explanations.B: Staples don't provide sufficient holding power for underlayment
explanations.C: Ring shank nails or screws at 150 mm edges and 200 mm field spacing prevent movement and squeaking while creating a stable surface
explanations.D: Proper fastening is essential to prevent movement

questions.question: What expansion gap should be left around the perimeter when installing laminate flooring?

explanations.A: Laminate flooring requires expansion space
explanations.B: This gap is too small for laminate movement
explanations.C: Still insufficient for proper expansion
explanations.D: Laminate flooring requires 10-12 mm expansion gap around all fixed objects to allow for expansion/contraction with humidity changes

questions.question: What should be done to underlayment seams before installing vinyl flooring?

explanations.A: Unsealed seams will telegraph through vinyl
explanations.B: Underlayment seams should be filled with floor patch compound and sanded smooth to prevent telegraphing through vinyl flooring
explanations.C: Tape alone doesn't create a smooth transition
explanations.D: Caulk is inappropriate for this application

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of access flooring (raised floor) systems?

options.B: To provide concealed space for electrical, data, and HVAC distribution

explanations.A: While they may provide some sound benefits, this isn't the primary purpose
explanations.B: Access flooring creates a raised floor system with accessible underfloor space for flexible distribution of power, data, and HVAC in commercial settings
explanations.C: Leveling is a secondary benefit, not the primary purpose
explanations.D: Cushioning is not the main function of access flooring

questions.question: In which direction should hardwood flooring typically be installed?

explanations.A: While often coinciding with joist direction, joist orientation is the determining factor
explanations.B: Hardwood flooring should run perpendicular to floor joists for maximum strength and to minimize deflection
explanations.C: Diagonal installation wastes material and is uncommon except for design purposes
explanations.D: Direction is critical for structural performance

questions.question: How should underlayment panel joints be oriented relative to subfloor joints?

explanations.A: Aligned joints create weak points and will telegraph through
explanations.B: Underlayment joints should be offset from subfloor joints to prevent weak areas and seam telegraphing through finished flooring
explanations.C: While perpendicular is one way to offset, any offset pattern works
explanations.D: Joint alignment significantly affects floor performance

questions.question: What is the purpose of underlayment pad for laminate flooring?

options.B: To provide moisture barrier, sound reduction, and cushioning

explanations.A: Laminate is a floating floor; pad isn't for structural support
explanations.B: Underlayment pad provides moisture barrier (if not built-in), reduces sound transmission, provides minor cushioning, and helps laminate float smoothly
explanations.C: Leveling requires floor preparation, not pad
explanations.D: Laminate flooring floats; it's not adhered

questions.question: What type of underlayment is recommended under ceramic tile?

options.C: Cement board or appropriate backer board

explanations.A: Plywood alone doesn't provide adequate dimensional stability for tile
explanations.B: Particleboard deteriorates with moisture and isn't suitable
explanations.C: Cement board or similar backer board provides a stable, moisture-resistant substrate specifically designed for tile installation
explanations.D: Foam compresses and is completely unsuitable for tile

questions.question: How should the first row of hardwood flooring be fastened?

options.A: Face-nailed near the wall edge, covered by baseboard

explanations.A: The first row should be face-nailed close to the wall where baseboard will cover the nails, providing a secure starting point for the floor
explanations.B: The first row can't be blind-nailed due to lack of access for nailer
explanations.C: Glue alone doesn't provide adequate holding for the starter row
explanations.D: Solid hardwood is typically nailed, not floated

questions.question: What is the typical height range for commercial access flooring systems?

explanations.A: This height is too shallow for effective cable management
explanations.B: While within range, this is on the low end
explanations.C: Access flooring typically ranges from 150-600 mm to accommodate various amounts of cabling, ductwork, and ease of access
explanations.D: This height is excessive and creates accessibility issues

questions.question: What is the maximum gap acceptable between underlayment panels?

explanations.A: Panels need slight gap for expansion
explanations.B: A 1 mm gap allows for expansion while being small enough to fill effectively and prevent telegraphing
explanations.C: This gap is too large and will be visible through flooring
explanations.D: This gap is excessive and creates weak points

questions.question: What moisture content should hardwood flooring have before installation?

explanations.A: This is slightly too dry for most installations
explanations.B: Hardwood should be 6-9% moisture content (within 2% of subfloor) to prevent excessive expansion or contraction after installation
explanations.C: This moisture level is too high and will cause shrinkage
explanations.D: This moisture content is far too high and will cause severe problems

questions.question: What is the purpose of staggering end joints in hardwood flooring?

options.B: To distribute structural loads and prevent weak lines

explanations.A: While appearance is enhanced, structural reasons are primary
explanations.B: Staggering end joints (typically 150-200 mm minimum) distributes loads and prevents continuous weak lines that could cause floor failure
explanations.C: Using short pieces is a result, not the purpose
explanations.D: Proper staggering actually requires more careful planning, not cost savings

questions.question: What type of panels are commonly used for access flooring systems?

options.B: Steel, aluminum, or composite panels on pedestals

explanations.A: Wood is not typical for commercial access flooring
explanations.B: Access flooring uses steel, aluminum, or wood composite panels supported by adjustable pedestals, allowing for level installation and easy removal
explanations.C: Concrete is too heavy and not removable for access
explanations.D: Foam cannot support floor loads

questions.question: What is the standard width of interior door jambs?

explanations.A: This is only correct for 2x4 walls
explanations.B: This is only correct for 2x4 walls with 13 mm drywall both sides
explanations.C: This is only correct for 2x6 walls
explanations.D: Interior jamb width should match the finished wall thickness, which varies based on framing and drywall installation

questions.question: What is the standard thickness for interior doors in residential construction?

explanations.A: This thickness is too thin for standard doors
explanations.B: Standard interior doors are 35 mm (1-3/8 in.) thick, providing adequate strength while being lighter than exterior doors
explanations.C: This is the thickness for exterior doors
explanations.D: This thickness is excessive for interior applications

questions.subtask: F-19.04 Installs interior door and window hardware
questions.question: What is the standard height for interior door handles from the finished floor?

explanations.A: This height is too low for comfortable operation
explanations.B: While sometimes used, this is below standard height
explanations.C: 965 mm (38 in.) to the center of the handle is standard height for interior door hardware, providing comfortable access for most users
explanations.D: This height is too high and uncomfortable

questions.question: How should interior door jambs be secured to the framing?

options.B: Shimmed and screwed/nailed through shims into framing

explanations.A: Face nailing alone doesn't provide adequate stability
explanations.B: Jambs should be shimmed at hinge and strike locations, then fastened through shims into framing to maintain proper spacing and prevent warping
explanations.C: Adhesive alone is insufficient for door frame stability
explanations.D: Friction fit provides no secure attachment

questions.question: What is the standard rough opening width for a 760 mm (30 in.) interior door?

explanations.A: This is the door width, not the rough opening
explanations.B: This opening is too tight for jamb and shimming
explanations.C: Rough opening should be approximately 50 mm (2 in.) wider than door width to accommodate jambs, shimming, and adjustment
explanations.D: This opening is too wide and wastes space

questions.subtask: F-19.04 Installs interior door and window hardware
questions.question: How many hinges are typically required for a standard interior door?

explanations.A: One hinge is insufficient for door support
explanations.B: Standard interior doors typically use two hinges; three may be used for heavy or tall doors
explanations.C: Three hinges are used for heavy doors but exceed standard requirements
explanations.D: Four hinges are excessive for standard interior doors

questions.question: What clearance should be maintained between the door and floor for carpet?

explanations.A: This clearance is too tight for carpet
explanations.B: Still insufficient for carpet pile
explanations.C: Doors over carpet should have 13-19 mm clearance to allow for carpet pile and padding while maintaining proper operation
explanations.D: This clearance is excessive and looks unprofessional

questions.question: What should be verified before installing a pre-hung interior door?

options.B: Rough opening is square, plumb, and correct size

explanations.A: Swing direction is important but rough opening condition is critical
explanations.B: The rough opening must be verified as square, plumb, level, and properly sized before installation to ensure proper door operation
explanations.C: Hardware is secondary to opening preparation
explanations.D: Proper verification prevents installation problems

questions.subtask: F-19.04 Installs interior door and window hardware
questions.question: What is the typical backset for interior door locksets?

explanations.A: This backset is too shallow for standard doors
explanations.B: Standard interior door lockset backset is 60 mm (2-3/8 in.) from door edge to center of knob, though 70 mm is also common
explanations.C: This is an alternative standard backset but not the most common
explanations.D: This backset is excessive for residential doors

questions.question: How should bifold doors be adjusted for proper operation?

options.C: Adjust both top and bottom pivots for alignment and smooth operation

explanations.A: Top pivot alone doesn't provide complete adjustment
explanations.B: Bottom pivot alone is insufficient for proper alignment
explanations.C: Both top and bottom pivots must be adjusted to achieve proper door alignment, smooth operation, and even gaps
explanations.D: Bifold doors have multiple adjustment points

questions.question: Where should shims be placed when installing an interior door frame?

options.B: Behind hinges, strike plate, and mid-height on both sides

explanations.A: Top corners alone don't provide adequate support
explanations.B: Shims should be placed behind all hinges, behind the strike plate, and at mid-height to prevent frame distortion and ensure proper door operation
explanations.C: Bottom shimming alone leaves the frame unsupported
explanations.D: Strategic shimming at stress points is essential

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of interior windows in residential construction?

options.B: To allow natural light between rooms

explanations.A: Interior windows provide no structural support
explanations.B: Interior windows (like transom windows) allow natural light to pass between rooms, making interior spaces brighter without exterior exposure
explanations.C: Interior windows rarely open for ventilation
explanations.D: Interior windows actually reduce sound insulation between rooms

questions.question: What is the typical reveal around an interior door between jamb and casing?

explanations.A: Flush installation is difficult and doesn't provide a clean line
explanations.B: A 3-6 mm reveal creates a consistent shadow line around the door and allows for minor imperfections in the jamb
explanations.C: This reveal is too large and looks disproportionate
explanations.D: This reveal is excessive and unprofessional

questions.subtask: F-19.04 Installs interior door and window hardware
questions.question: How should hinge screws be positioned in an interior door jamb?

options.A: All short screws into jamb only
options.B: All long screws through jamb into framing
options.C: At least one long screw per hinge through jamb into framing

explanations.A: Jamb-only attachment may not provide adequate holding
explanations.B: All long screws is acceptable but may split jamb
explanations.C: At least one screw per hinge should be long enough (typically 75 mm) to penetrate through jamb and shims into solid framing
explanations.D: Proper screw attachment is essential for door support

questions.question: What is the standard height for interior doors?

explanations.A: This height is below standard
explanations.B: Close but not the standard measurement
explanations.C: Standard interior door height is 2040 mm (6 ft. 8 in.) or 80 inches, providing adequate clearance for most people
explanations.D: This is taller than standard, used for special applications

questions.question: What material is commonly used for interior door jambs?

options.B: Pine, poplar, or finger-jointed primed wood

explanations.A: Hardwood is sometimes used but not the most common
explanations.B: Pine, poplar, or finger-jointed primed wood are standard materials, offering good workability and paint-grade finish
explanations.C: Particleboard lacks the strength for door jambs
explanations.D: Plastic is rarely used for jambs in residential construction

questions.subtask: F-19.04 Installs interior door and window hardware
questions.question: What is the purpose of the strike plate on an interior door?

options.B: To protect the jamb and receive the latch bolt

explanations.A: While visible, the strike plate has an important function
explanations.B: The strike plate reinforces the jamb and provides a precise, durable receptacle for the latch bolt
explanations.C: Door stops control swing, not strike plates
explanations.D: Weatherstripping is used on exterior doors

questions.question: How should pocket doors be maintained for smooth operation?

options.B: Keep tracks clean and properly aligned with good rollers

explanations.A: Oil can attract dust and debris, causing problems
explanations.B: Smooth operation requires clean tracks, proper alignment, and functional rollers; lubrication should be dry-type (silicone spray)
explanations.C: While maintenance helps, this doesn't address track condition
explanations.D: Properly installed pocket doors last for years

questions.question: What is the purpose of a door stop on an interior jamb?

options.B: To position the door in the closed position and prevent over-swing

explanations.A: Door stops provide no structural support
explanations.B: The door stop creates a positive stop for the door in closed position and prevents it from swinging through the frame
explanations.C: Hardware attaches to the jamb face, not the stop
explanations.D: While affecting appearance, function is primary

questions.subtask: F-19.04 Installs interior door and window hardware
questions.question: What hole diameter is typically required for a standard interior door knob?

explanations.A: This hole is too small for standard locksets
explanations.B: Standard interior door locksets require a 54 mm (2-1/8 in.) hole through the door face for the knob mechanism
explanations.C: This hole is too large for standard locksets
explanations.D: This hole is far too large

questions.question: What is the recommended gap between door edge and jamb on the latch side?

explanations.A: This gap is too tight and may cause binding
explanations.B: A 3 mm (1/8 in.) gap allows smooth operation while maintaining a neat appearance
explanations.C: This gap is slightly too wide and may look sloppy
explanations.D: This gap is excessive and unprofessional

questions.question: How should glass be secured in an interior window frame?

options.B: Points or clips, with glazing compound or stops

explanations.A: Adhesive alone may not provide adequate security
explanations.B: Glass should be secured with glazier's points or clips, then sealed with compound or held with removable stops for safety and ease of replacement
explanations.C: Friction fit is insecure and dangerous
explanations.D: Screws cannot go through glass without special drilling

questions.question: What is the typical width of a standard bedroom door?

explanations.A: This width is typically used for closets, not bedrooms
explanations.B: This is below standard for bedroom doors
explanations.C: Standard bedroom door width is 760 mm (30 in.), providing adequate access for furniture and meeting code requirements
explanations.D: This width is wider than standard, often used for main entries

questions.subtask: F-19.04 Installs interior door and window hardware
questions.question: How should door casing miters be secured at corners?

explanations.A: Glue alone may not hold miters closed long-term
explanations.B: Face nailing doesn't secure the miter joint itself
explanations.C: Miters should be glued and pin-nailed through the joint to pull corners tight and prevent opening from wood movement
explanations.D: Miters must be secured to prevent gaps

questions.question: What is the proper sequence for installing a split-jamb door?

options.A: Install both halves together from one side
options.B: Install one half from each side, interlock at center
options.D: Hang door first, then add jambs

explanations.A: Split-jambs are designed for two-sided installation
explanations.B: One jamb half is installed from each side of the wall and they interlock at the center, eliminating the need for casing nails through the jamb
explanations.C: Standard jamb procedure doesn't apply to split-jambs
explanations.D: The door comes pre-hung in the jamb assembly

questions.question: What causes a door to bind on the hinge side?

explanations.A: If the hinge jamb bows outward (away from door stop), the door edge binds against the jamb
explanations.B: Inward bow would create a gap, not binding
explanations.C: Strike plate alignment affects latching, not hinge binding
explanations.D: A narrow door would create gaps, not binding

questions.subtask: F-19.04 Installs interior door and window hardware
questions.question: What is the purpose of door casing?

options.B: To cover the gap between jamb and wall and provide finished appearance

explanations.A: Casing provides no structural support
explanations.B: Casing (trim) covers the gap between door jamb and wall surface, concealing the rough opening while providing decorative finish
explanations.C: The door stop controls swing, not casing
explanations.D: Shimming holds the jamb square, not casing

questions.question: How much clearance is needed for a sliding bypass door to operate properly?

explanations.A: Tight fit will cause binding and damage
explanations.B: Bypass doors need minimum 6 mm clearance between them to slide smoothly without binding or rubbing
explanations.C: This clearance is more than necessary
explanations.D: This gap is excessive and looks unprofessional

questions.question: What is the purpose of head clearance above an interior door?

options.B: To allow for framing settlement and door swing clearance
options.D: No purpose; doors should fit tightly

explanations.A: Head clearance has practical purposes
explanations.B: Head clearance (typically 3-6 mm) allows for minor building settlement and ensures the door doesn't bind on the head jamb during operation
explanations.C: Lighting is separate from clearance requirements
explanations.D: Some clearance is essential for proper operation

questions.subtask: F-19.04 Installs interior door and window hardware
questions.question: What size finishing nails are typically used for interior door casing?

explanations.A: This length is too short for adequate holding
explanations.B: Still too short to reach framing behind drywall
explanations.C: 64 mm (2-1/2 in.) finishing nails provide adequate length to penetrate through casing, drywall, and into framing for secure attachment
explanations.D: This length is longer than necessary for casing

questions.question: What should be done if a door swings open or closed by itself?

options.B: Adjust the hinge jamb to be perfectly plumb

explanations.A: A door closer is unnecessary for a properly installed door
explanations.B: Self-closing or opening indicates the hinge jamb is not plumb; adjusting shims to make it perfectly vertical solves the problem
explanations.C: Door replacement is unnecessary for a plumb issue
explanations.D: Additional hinges won't solve a plumb problem

questions.question: What type of glass is recommended for interior windows near stairs or in other hazardous locations?

explanations.A: Annealed glass breaks into dangerous shards
explanations.B: Tempered or laminated safety glass should be used in hazardous locations to reduce injury risk if broken
explanations.C: While safe, plastic is not required and may not be preferred
explanations.D: Building codes require safety glass in specific locations

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a backer board when fabricating trim?

options.B: To provide support behind thin or built-up trim pieces

explanations.A: Weight is not a purpose of backer boards
explanations.B: Backer boards provide support behind complex or built-up trim assemblies, creating a stable nailing surface and preventing flexing
explanations.C: Backer boards are hidden and don't affect appearance
explanations.D: Waterproofing is not the function of interior backer boards

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: What is the standard height for installing chair rail molding?

explanations.A: This height is too low for chair rail
explanations.B: This is below typical chair rail height
explanations.C: Chair rail is typically installed 860-1070 mm (34-42 in.) from the floor, with 915 mm (36 in.) being most common
explanations.D: This height is too high and defeats the purpose

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the maximum variation allowed between stair risers in a flight?

explanations.A: While ideal, this tolerance is tighter than code requires
explanations.B: Riser height variation should not exceed 6 mm (1/4 in.) in a flight to prevent tripping hazards and meet building codes
explanations.C: This variation is too large and creates a tripping hazard
explanations.D: This variation is dangerous and violates code

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: How should baseboard be fastened to walls?

options.B: Nailed into bottom plate and studs

explanations.A: Adhesive alone may not hold long-term
explanations.B: Baseboard should be nailed into the wall bottom plate and into studs where possible to ensure secure attachment
explanations.C: Screws are unnecessary and screw heads are difficult to conceal
explanations.D: Friction fit provides no secure attachment

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the purpose of a coping cut in trim carpentry?

options.B: To join inside corners by cutting trim profile to match adjoining piece

explanations.A: Coping is functional, not decorative
explanations.B: A coped joint cuts the profile of one trim piece to fit tightly against the face of another, creating tight inside corners that won't gap with wood movement
explanations.C: Outside corners typically use mitered joints
explanations.D: Coping is a joining method, not an attachment method

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the minimum headroom required for interior stairs?

explanations.A: This headroom is below code minimum
explanations.B: Minimum headroom for interior stairs is 1950 mm (77 in.) measured vertically from stair nosing to overhead obstruction
explanations.C: While providing better clearance, this exceeds minimum
explanations.D: This headroom is more than required

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: What is the purpose of crown molding?

options.B: To create decorative transition between wall and ceiling

explanations.A: Crown molding provides no structural support
explanations.B: Crown molding creates an attractive transition between walls and ceiling, concealing the joint and adding visual interest
explanations.C: While it may conceal some wiring, this isn't its primary purpose
explanations.D: Crown molding has minimal acoustic effect

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What angle is typically used for mitering outside corners in trim work?

explanations.A: This angle is too acute for standard corners
explanations.B: Outside corners are typically mitered at 45 degrees on each piece to create a 90-degree corner
explanations.C: This angle is too obtuse for right-angle corners
explanations.D: This is the corner angle itself, not the miter cut

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the minimum tread depth for interior stairs?

explanations.A: This tread depth is below code minimum
explanations.B: Still below minimum for interior stairs
explanations.C: Minimum tread depth for interior stairs is 250 mm (10 in.) measured horizontally from riser to riser
explanations.D: While providing better footing, this exceeds minimum requirements

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: How should trim be finished at corners where walls are slightly out of square?

options.B: Adjust miter angles to match actual wall angles

explanations.A: Forcing square trim creates gaps and looks unprofessional
explanations.B: Miter angles should be adjusted to match actual wall angles (e.g., 44/46 degrees instead of 45/45) for tight-fitting corners
explanations.C: While caulk helps, properly cut angles are essential
explanations.D: Real-world walls are rarely perfectly square

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the purpose of a scarf joint in trim work?

options.A: To join pieces at outside corners
options.B: To join two pieces end-to-end on a long run
options.C: To join trim at inside corners

explanations.A: Outside corners use miter joints, not scarf joints
explanations.B: A scarf joint joins two pieces end-to-end using overlapping angled cuts (typically 45 degrees), hiding the seam better than a butt joint
explanations.C: Inside corners use coped or mitered joints
explanations.D: This describes fastening, not joining trim pieces

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the maximum riser height for interior residential stairs?

explanations.A: This is below maximum and creates more steps than necessary
explanations.B: Still below the maximum allowed
explanations.C: Maximum riser height for residential interior stairs is typically 200 mm (7-3/4 in.) to ensure comfortable, safe climbing
explanations.D: This height exceeds code maximum

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: What is the recommended height for wainscoting?

explanations.A: This height is too low for typical wainscoting
explanations.B: Still below standard wainscoting height
explanations.C: Wainscoting typically ranges from 900-1200 mm (36-48 in.) high, with one-third of wall height being a common guideline
explanations.D: This height is too tall and approaches full-height paneling

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What tool is typically used to create a coped joint?

explanations.A: Circular saws cannot make the detailed cuts required for coping
explanations.B: A coping saw (or jigsaw for power cutting) can make the detailed curved cuts needed to follow the trim profile
explanations.C: Table saws cannot make coped cuts
explanations.D: While chisels can refine coped joints, they alone cannot create them

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is a stringer in stair construction?

options.A: The decorative trim on stair sides
options.B: The supporting member that carries treads and risers

explanations.A: Decorative trim is called skirt board or stringer cover
explanations.B: Stringers are the structural members (typically three per stair run) that are cut or routed to support the treads and risers
explanations.C: Handrail supports are called balusters or newel posts
explanations.D: Nosing is the tread projection, not a structural member

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: How should baseboard cope at inside corners?

options.C: One piece square-cut to wall, other piece coped to fit

explanations.A: Mitered inside corners gap open with wood movement
explanations.B: Butt cuts don't provide a professional appearance
explanations.C: One baseboard runs square to the wall, while the adjacent piece is coped to fit its profile, creating a tight joint that resists gapping
explanations.D: Random overlap is unprofessional and weak

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the purpose of back-cutting a miter?

options.B: To ensure tight fit at the visible edge even if angles are slightly off

explanations.A: Back-cutting improves joints, doesn't weaken them
explanations.B: Back-cutting removes material from behind the miter, ensuring the visible front edges meet tightly even if the angle is slightly imperfect
explanations.C: Back-cutting is not visible and has no decorative purpose
explanations.D: Back-cutting removes material but isn't about saving it

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the minimum width for interior residential stairs?

explanations.A: This width is below code minimum
explanations.B: Minimum interior stair width is 860 mm (34 in.) clear width between walls or handrails to allow safe passage
explanations.C: While providing better access, this exceeds minimum requirements
explanations.D: This width is wider than minimum required

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: What is the purpose of a shoe molding (base shoe)?

options.B: To cover gap between baseboard and flooring

explanations.A: Shoe molding is named for its shape, not function with footwear
explanations.B: Shoe molding covers the gap between baseboard and flooring, accommodating floor irregularities while providing a finished appearance
explanations.C: Shoe molding provides no structural support
explanations.D: Marking height is not the function of shoe molding

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is a return in finish carpentry?

options.A: Taking trim back to the supplier
options.B: A small piece that turns trim into a wall or terminates it
options.C: The profit margin on trim work

explanations.A: This describes a material return, not a carpentry term
explanations.B: A return is a small mitered piece that turns trim back into a wall or creates a finished end, rather than leaving raw end grain exposed
explanations.C: Financial terms are not relevant to fabrication
explanations.D: This describes rework, not a return

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the purpose of a nosing on stair treads?

options.B: To increase effective tread depth and prevent toe stubbing

explanations.A: While enhancing appearance, nosing has a functional purpose
explanations.B: The nosing (typically 19-38 mm projection) increases effective tread depth for safer footing and creates a visual edge to prevent toe stubbing
explanations.C: Risers are supported by stringers, not nosing
explanations.D: Handrails attach to balusters and newel posts, not nosing

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: How should window trim (casing) be installed?

options.B: With a reveal (typically 3-6 mm) from window jamb edge
options.C: Overlapping the window frame by 25 mm

explanations.A: Flush installation is difficult and doesn't create a clean shadow line
explanations.B: Window casing should be set back 3-6 mm from the jamb edge, creating a reveal that provides a clean visual line and accommodates minor imperfections
explanations.C: Overlapping prevents proper window operation
explanations.D: This gap is too large and looks unprofessional

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the purpose of priming the back of wood trim before installation?

options.B: To seal wood and reduce moisture absorption that causes warping

explanations.A: Weight change is not a purpose of back-priming
explanations.B: Back-priming seals the wood, reducing moisture absorption from walls and preventing warping, cupping, and paint failure
explanations.C: Back-priming isn't visible and doesn't affect appearance
explanations.D: Back-priming doesn't affect installation difficulty

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the maximum projection allowed for a stair tread nosing?

explanations.A: This projection is minimal and below typical standards
explanations.B: While common, this isn't the maximum allowed
explanations.C: Maximum nosing projection is typically 38 mm (1-1/2 in.) to prevent tripping while providing adequate tread depth
explanations.D: This projection is excessive and creates a tripping hazard

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: What is the purpose of picture rail molding?

options.B: To provide a decorative element and hanging point for artwork without wall damage

explanations.A: Picture rails are not designed for shelf support
explanations.B: Picture rail allows hanging of artwork from hooks without putting holes in walls, while adding decorative architectural interest
explanations.C: While it may define color zones, this isn't its primary purpose
explanations.D: Wiring concealment is not the function of picture rail

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the purpose of using a biscuit joiner in trim fabrication?

options.B: To create strong, aligned joints using oval wooden biscuits

explanations.A: Length cutting uses saws, not biscuit joiners
explanations.B: A biscuit joiner cuts matching slots in mating pieces; compressed wood biscuits inserted with glue create strong, self-aligning joints
explanations.C: Sanding requires sanders, not biscuit joiners
explanations.D: Finish application is separate from joinery

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the minimum handrail height for interior stairs?

explanations.A: This height is below code minimum
explanations.B: Minimum interior stair handrail height is 865 mm (34 in.) measured vertically from the nosing to the top of the handrail
explanations.C: While acceptable, this exceeds the minimum
explanations.D: This height is higher than minimum required

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: How should crown molding be nailed?

options.C: Into both ceiling joists and wall top plate

explanations.A: Nailing to ceiling only doesn't secure the bottom edge
explanations.B: Nailing to walls only doesn't secure the top edge
explanations.C: Crown molding should be nailed into ceiling joists at the top and into wall top plate at the bottom for secure attachment
explanations.D: Adhesive alone is insufficient for crown molding support

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is a plinth block?

options.B: A decorative block at the base of door casing where it meets baseboard

explanations.A: Foundation blocks are not called plinth blocks in trim work
explanations.B: A plinth block is a decorative, slightly thicker block installed at the bottom of door casing, eliminating the need to miter baseboard to casing
explanations.C: Ceiling medallions are separate decorative elements
explanations.D: While newels may have plinths, this isn't the primary definition

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is a closed stringer?

options.A: A stringer that is enclosed in drywall
options.B: A stringer with a continuous straight edge where treads are housed into the side
options.C: A stringer that has been sealed with finish
options.D: A temporary support removed after construction

explanations.A: Drywall enclosure doesn't define a closed stringer
explanations.B: A closed stringer maintains a straight edge with treads and risers housed (dadoed) into its side, creating a clean finished appearance
explanations.C: Finish sealing doesn't define stringer type
explanations.D: Permanent stringers are not temporary supports

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: What is the purpose of corner guards?

options.B: To protect vulnerable outside corners from damage

explanations.A: While enhancing appearance, corner guards have a protective function
explanations.B: Corner guards protect outside corners in high-traffic areas from impacts that would damage drywall and paint
explanations.C: Corner guards provide no structural support
explanations.D: Wiring runs inside walls, not behind corner guards

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the purpose of a reveal in trim work?

options.B: To create a small offset between surfaces that defines edges and accommodates imperfections

explanations.A: Reveals don't expose substrate; they create shadow lines
explanations.B: A reveal (typically 3-6 mm) creates a visual shadow line that defines elements and provides tolerance for minor irregularities in surfaces
explanations.C: This describes removal, not a design element
explanations.D: Length adjustment is separate from reveal creation

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the purpose of stair skirt board?

options.B: To provide finished trim along stairway walls, covering stringer edges

explanations.A: Stringers support treads, not skirt boards
explanations.B: Skirt board is trim that runs along the wall beside stairs, providing a finished appearance and covering the stringer edge and wall joint
explanations.C: Handrails are separate safety features
explanations.D: Tread surface treatments prevent slipping, not skirt boards

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: How should rosettes be used in door and window trim?

options.B: As decorative corner blocks eliminating the need for miter joints

explanations.A: Rosettes provide no structural support
explanations.B: Rosettes are decorative corner blocks installed at trim intersections (especially door head corners), allowing square-cut trim pieces instead of miters
explanations.C: Rosettes are commonly used on interior trim
explanations.D: Door stops are separate components

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the purpose of relief cuts when coping trim?

options.B: To allow the coping saw to navigate tight curves without binding

explanations.A: Relief cuts improve cutting, they don't intentionally weaken trim
explanations.B: Relief cuts are straight cuts into the profile that remove waste material, allowing the coping saw blade to navigate curves without binding or breaking
explanations.C: Relief cuts are functional, not decorative
explanations.D: Relief cuts are part of the cutting process, not attachment

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is a winder in stair construction?

options.B: A wedge-shaped tread used to change stair direction

explanations.A: This describes a hypothetical tool, not a stair component
explanations.B: A winder is a wedge-shaped tread (wider on one end than the other) used to turn stairs, typically replacing a landing to save space
explanations.C: Handrail components have different names
explanations.D: Finishes are not called winders

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: What is the standard method for joining baseboard at outside corners?

explanations.A: Butt joints at outside corners look unprofessional
explanations.B: Outside corners use 45-degree miters on each piece, creating a clean 90-degree corner when joined
explanations.C: Lap joints are not used for baseboard corners
explanations.D: Coped joints are for inside corners, not outside

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the purpose of blocking behind built-up trim?

options.B: To provide solid nailing surface and support for multiple trim layers

explanations.A: Weight is not the purpose of blocking
explanations.B: Blocking behind complex, built-up trim assemblies provides solid backing for secure fastening and prevents flexing of the assembly
explanations.C: Blocking is hidden and doesn't affect appearance
explanations.D: Blocking fills space, it doesn't create gaps

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.question: What is the maximum handrail height for interior stairs?

explanations.A: This height is below maximum but above minimum
explanations.B: Maximum handrail height is typically 965 mm (38 in.) measured vertically from nosing, keeping rails within comfortable reach
explanations.C: This height exceeds typical code maximum
explanations.D: This height is too high and uncomfortable for most users

questions.taskTitle: Constructs and installs finish components and stairs
questions.subtask: F-20.02 Installs finish components and accessories
questions.question: How should nail holes be treated in painted trim?

options.B: Filled with wood filler or spackling after installation

explanations.A: Visible nail holes look unprofessional
explanations.B: Nail holes should be filled after installation using wood filler or spackling compound, then sanded smooth before painting
explanations.C: Pre-filling is impractical as installation creates new nail holes
explanations.D: Tape is not an appropriate finish treatment
